definition: to stand out among one's peers (idiom)/to excel

to go out/to come out/to occur/to produce/to go beyond/to rise/to put forth/to happen/(used after a verb to indicate an outward direction or a positive result)/classifier for dramas, plays, operas etc
variant of 出[chu1] (classifier for plays or chapters of classical novels)
man/person/people/CL:個|个[ge4],位[wei4]
suffix for nouns
head/hair style/the top/end/beginning or end/a stub/remnant/chief/boss/side/aspect/first/leading/classifier for pigs or livestock/CL:個|个[ge4]
earth/ground/field/place/land/CL:片[pian4]
-ly/structural particle: used before a verb or adjective, linking it to preceding modifying adverbial adjunct

sentences.english: A: You need to work hard to get ahead in this company.
sentences.chinese: 在这家公司要想出人头地，就得努力工作。

sentences.english: They know that their offspring will need English to get ahead.
sentences.chinese: 他们的后代为了出人头地将需要英语。

sentences.english: I never want to view myself as any different or any better than anyone else.
sentences.chinese: 我从来没有想过要活得异于凡人或出人头地。

sentences.english: After be released from prison, turn and careerism, aspire stand out.
sentences.chinese: 出狱后，转而追求名利，立志出人头地。

sentences.english: He desired not to be pinnacled, but to sink into the crowd.
sentences.chinese: 他不想出人头地，只愿深入群众之中。

sentences.english: He desired not to be pinnacled, but sink into the crowd.
sentences.chinese: 他不想出人头地，只愿深入群众之中。

sentences.english: First with wit is divided into two unsuccessful preeminence.
sentences.chinese: 先把才子分为出人头地与怀才不遇两种。
难道你不想出人头地吗？

sentences.english: A man has to strike out for himself if he wants to get ahead.
sentences.chinese: 一个人要想出人头地，就得自己去打天下。

sentences.english: I will signalize you in the filmdom in two years.
sentences.chinese: 我将在两年内使你在电影界出人头地。

sentences.english: The big thing in LA seems to be fame.
sentences.chinese: 在洛杉矶，出人头地似乎事关重大。

sentences.english: He was eager to get out of the (common) ruck and distinguish himself in some way.
sentences.chinese: 他渴望出人头地，在某方面与众不同。

definition: to bring honor to one's ancestors
lit. the divine steed Feihuang gallops (idiom)/fig. to achieve meteoric success in one's career
splendor shines on the family's door (idiom)/fig. to bring honor to one's family
to win success and recognition (idiom)
to make it/to be somebody
to achieve or accomplish goals
not having to worry about clothes and food (idiom)/to be provided with the basic necessities
to rapidly go up in the world/meteoric rise (of a career, social position etc)
to be promoted and gain wealth (idiom)
to come back to one's hometown in silken robes (idiom); to return in glory
to bear hardships
to earn a fortune
aspiration/ambition
reaching heaven in a single bound (idiom); (esp. with negative: don't expect) instant success
to strive for mastery (idiom); aiming for the best result/to have high ambitions
both fame and fortune (idiom)/both virtue and reward
